_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: All manual process - procedures ensure safe storage and movement of containers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The distribution facility is located at 120 E Mt Gallant Road in Rock Hill, South Carolina, in an industrial park.  

The company is a member of the Alliance for Chemical Distribution dedicated to the code of management practice of the Responsible Distribution Process. The safe management of chemical products is considered priority to minimize the risk to our community, environment, and personnel. 

Additionally, Chemsolv, Inc. manages the facility in compliance with all Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA), Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Virginia Department of Environmental Protection (DEQ) and the United States Department of Transportation (USDOT) regulations.  

To ensure the facility continues to operate in a safe and responsible manner in compliance with all regulations, an extensive risk management system has been developed and integrated into our operating procedures. 

Significant components of the system include training, operating procedures for chemical handling, inspection, maintenance, emergency response, and incident management. These procedures provided to responsible personnel and management's continual compliance oversight ensures safe chemical management.

The CEO, Director of Environmental, Health, Safety & Quality, and the Plant Manager are designated as having the primary responsibility and accountability to ensure the plan and all components are in compliance and implemented.

Stationary Source Description and Regulated Substances Handled

The facility is used for receipt, storage, and distribution of chemical products.  There is no reactive chemistry conducted at the site. 

Both liquid and dry chemicals are received, relabeled and placed in storage for shipment to industrial, agricultural, government, food, and cosmetic customers.  These packaged containers include pails, drums and totes. 

The containers are stored in

secured areas to prevent accidental damage and in an area away from equipment traffic and chemicals that may, during an incident, contribute to a release from these containers. Only authorized and trained personnel are permitted to handle the containers. 

Aqua ammonia arrives at the facility in 55-gallon drums and 275/330-gallon totes. The drums are palletized and single or double stacked in an area with limited access away from traffic. 

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The facility has an aggressive accidental release prevention program that is based upon employee training, chemical safety awareness, equipment and facility management. 

Training includes both the classroom environment and observation by management to verify competency. Classes are designed to achieve maximum results within the time period on an annual basis. Knowledge is evaluated by both verbal questioning for some classes during the training and some classes have written tests. Attendance is mandatory for all employees including packagers, maintenance, drivers, and warehouse personnel and verified by both the Director of Environmental, Health, Safety & Quality and the HR Manager. 

New employees are required to receive an extensive orientation to the operating procedures for each phase of the operation including Hazard Communication, Hazardous Material Transportation, Chemicals & Personal Hygiene, Forklift, Personal Protection Equipment, Respiratory Training, Site Security, Emergency Contingency, hazard recognition, Risk Management Program, and safe work practices. Additionally, the operators have specific spill response, clean-up, and emergency response training in the respective Learn to Earn matrix. 

Employees not having worked in a process receive an introduction by thorough procedural documentation review and pairing the employee with a person familiar with the process for an appropriate period. Management within the guidelines of the

program verifies competency of safe operating practices.

The company provides training according to the following regulatory and association requirements:

Hazard Communication
Site Security
Environmental Compliance Plan-Corporate Plan
Safety in the Workplace
Safety Code Book (Corporate Safety Book)
Lockout/Tagout
Confined Spaces
Accident Procedures
Personal Protective Equipment
Portable Fire Extinguishers
Chemicals & Personal Hygiene
Powered Industrial Trucks (forklifts)
  Safety Inspection and Maintenance
  Stability and Capacity
  Load Handling
  Traveling and Maneuvering
Railcar Offloading Procedures
Drum and Toting Procedures
Hazardous Materials
Personal Protection Equipment
Bloodborne Pathogens
Hazardous Chemical Containers
Tanker Loading/unloading procedures
How to Handle Corrosives
How to Handle Solvents
Respiratory Training
Emergency Contingency Plan
Heat Stress (prevention, identification, and first aid: heat rash, heat cramps, heat syncope, heat
exhaustion, and heat stroke)
Universal Waste (including mercury spills)
Hazard Reporting (and using the Hazard Reporting Form)
Safety Concepts (Incidents, near miss, unsafe acts/conditions, OSHA first aid, incident ratio model)
Chemical Spill Response
RCRA Training (annual third-party)
United States Department of Transportation Federal Highway Administration Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations and Research and Special Programs Administration
DOT HAZMAT (annual third-party)
Responsible Distribution Programs and Procedures
Alliance for Chemical Distribution Responsible Distribution Process
Facility Management
Product Stewardship
Waste Management
Community Outreach
Carrier Selection

Maintenance Systems

The program includes an aggressive maintenance and process inspection system to verify all systems are in proper working order and repairs are accomplished promptly to minimize the risk of release from equipment failure. 

Qualified and competent operators perform pre and post inspections for the transportation

equipment used to move product on the public roads and highways.  Chemsolv maintains the vehicles according to a strict schedule with a strong reputation in transportation equipment maintenance. 

All drums and totes are designed for and dedicated to specific products. Each container is inspected upon receipt and prior to off-site shipment. 

Material handling equipment such as fork lifts are inspected daily and each unit receives periodic maintenance according to a schedule. All equipment used in the handling of material are routinely inspected for defects and promptly removed from service when found defective. 

The loading and unloading areas for transport vehicles are on concrete surfaces. A release occurring during the loading or unloading of containers can be contained to this area. 

Materials stored within buildings are located in areas specific to their hazard class to prevent one group of hazard class from impacting another during an incident. 

All buildings are constructed of poured concrete floors to minimize the possibility of a release contacting the ground and impacting the environment. Equipment used in the areas to move containers is designed for their intended use. 

Storage areas are routinely inspected according to a schedule to minimize risks associated with improper material storage. 

The grounds are secured to prevent unauthorized access to the facility.

Five-year Accident History

Chemsolv has not incurred a reportable incident for aqua ammonia in the 5 years since the last RMP update. 

Emergency Response Program

The emergency response program document and procedures were developed when the Environmental Protection Agency enacted the Superfund Amendment and Reauthorization Act known as the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Program or SARA Title III. 

This program requires facilities having certain regulated substances in amounts exceeding threshold quantities to notify the Local Emergency Planning Committees (LEPC) and fir

e departments that would respond to the facility in an emergency of the existence of these substances. 

This information is updated annually and made available to the public through the LEPC. Documentation includes the chemical inventory of regulated substances, the container types and storage conditions, maximum amounts at the site during the year, average daily amounts and the number of days on site. 

In addition, site descriptions, drawings of the facility, locations within the facility of each chemical, surface area, equipment locations as well as emergency equipment are included in the documents. 

The emergency response and contingency plan developed and coordinated with local responders includes a description of emergency response equipment on site, contacts names and phone numbers, procedures for public notice, guidelines for notifying emergency response agencies and personnel, information gathering forms and methods and reports that must be completed and filed with regulatory agencies. 

The emergency response team is 40-hour HAZWOPER certified in response techniques. The program provides training for hazardous incident recognition, personnel protection equipment selection and use, characteristics of hazardous chemicals and the methods for response, cleanup and decontamination.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Plans are continually updated to improve management of chemicals and reduce the risks associated with handling chemical products. 

Chemsolv initiated a major improvement to its risk management through the implementation of a Chemsolv Safe Work Permits & Preliminary Risk Analysis (PRA) on 9/28/2018 that utilizes a checklist format and consolidates all work permits under one system. It asks the same questions that a thorough job briefing would ask, but in a systematic way by guiding through the major hazards in a checklist form. We review the checklist at the work site and mark which hazards are present. Yellow hazards must be addressed during the

completion of the step by step job plan, Red hazards require the completion of the appropriate work permit. The permits are basically additional checklists for the special hazards that are identified. The step by step plan analyzes the work for the hazards of each step. The hazards are identified and what will be done to control them. These are assigned to an individual and then we re-evaluate and decide if the hazards are adequately controlled. The PRA is required for all non-routine work, requires two people to issue and release, and allows us to systematically identify and control hazards in the workplace. This system does not change the original prohibition of "No hot work near any covered process" but emphasizes and enforces this safeguard to include ALL flammable processes. 

Plan updates are the result of coordination with local responders, inspections by regulatory agencies, training sessions, process changes, and new risk management programs and regulations enacted by the government. 

Presently all areas are being studied to identify technically, procedurally and economically feasible passive and active risk management strategies to further enhance the safe operation of the facility.
